text: 6 Minute English from the BBC
Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Neil.
speaker: Neil

text: And I'm Beth.
In this program, we'll be discussing the dinner table.
But we're not interested in food. We're talking about talking.
speaker: Neil

text: A lot can happen around the dinner table.
Gossip, arguments. You might meet the love of your life on a blind dinner date.
Or find out you're a great storyteller.
Neil, when you were younger, did you eat with your family around a dinner table?
We did! Eating at the table was an important ritual.
speaker: open up

text: It was something we did every day.
And quite often, it was the only time we could get together and chat.
I think there's something very comforting about eating good food
and being with the people you're closest to.
And now, I do the same with my own family.
The kids are more likely to open up.
Talk more easily about their day or something troubling them while they're eating.
Well, the dinner table is a space that families across the world get together at.
To not only eat, but chat.
And it's often the only point in the day or week that the whole family gathers together.
In this program, we'll be discussing how people behave at the table.
And of course, we'll be learning some useful new vocabulary as well.
But first I have a question for you, Beth.
speaker: Neil

text: In 2016, a couple from Germany won the world record for the fastest time to set a dinner table.
But how long did it take them?
Was it A, 25 seconds, B, 1 minute and 5 seconds, or C, 2 minutes and 5 seconds?
Surely not 25 seconds
speaker: Neil

text: I will guess 1 minute, 5 seconds.
OK, Beth, I'll reveal the answer later in the program.
speaker: Neil

text: Now, while eating with a group, you might feel that you need to act in a certain way
because of the people around you.
Philip Aperi, a psychotherapist and author, thinks we should try to be ourselves as much as possible
as she told BBC World Service Program, The Food Chain.
In any group, we find a role.
And if we're only in one group, if we're only ever with our family, we might think,
oh, I'm the funny one. He's the wise one.
We might think that's who we are.
And then we go to another group and then we find, oh, I'm the wise one.
And I think if you feel like you're assigned a role in your family,
I just think take that with a little bit of a pinch of salt.
When you spend time with the same group of people,
speaker: 'the funny one''the wise one''the … one'the tall one

text: you might start to think of yourself as the funny one or the wise one.
When we say the one, we describe a person by using a particular and prominent characteristic they have.
If you're very tall, you might be the tall one.
However, Philip Aperi says we should take these labels with a pinch of salt.
An idiom meaning you shouldn't believe or do everything you're told or that's expected of you.
Now, over time, interactions at the dinner table have changed.
speaker: childrenshould be seen and not heard

text: In the past, children were sometimes seated on a different table to adults,
or toles they should be seen and not heard.
An old-fashioned phrase emphasising that children should be quiet and always on their best behaviour.
Embraer Medos Fernandez, a writer and founder of Free Black Motherhood,
spoke about older generations' reactions to children asking awkward questions at the dinner table
to BBC World Service Program, the food chain.
So it's a mixed bag.
It's overwhelmingly positive, but I also know that it is kind of a bit of a culture shock
for them to hear my children ask the questions that they ask,
because our children haven't really been raised with that line of demarcation
between the adult table and the key at table.
Embraer says that the older generations' reactions to her children's questions at the table
can be a mixed bag.
speaker: a mixed bagA mixed bagculture shock

text: A mixed bag is a situation that can have positive and negative aspects.
She also says that it's a culture shock for them, a sense of feeling uncertain
because you're in a different environment to usual.
OK, Beth, I think it's time I revealed the answer to my question.
I asked you what the world record is for the fastest time to set a dinner table.
And I said it was one minute and five seconds.
And that was the right answer. That's not very long, is it?
speaker: Beth

text: OK, let's recap the vocabulary we've learned from this program, starting with open up.
A phrasal verb meaning speak more easily than usual, particularly about worries or problems.
If someone is the funny one or the wise one, they're labelled by that particular characteristic.
To take something with a pinch of salt means you shouldn't believe everything you're told.
speaker: 'the funny one''the wise one'

text: Children should be seen and not heard is an old-fashioned phrase that means children should be
speaker: Children should be seen and not heard

text: quiet and behave well.
A mixed bag means something has both positive and negative aspects.
And finally, a culture shock is an uncertain feeling because you're in a new environment.
speaker: culture shock

text: Once again, our six minutes are up.
